items.content_text:
Apollo will close down on June 30th 🔗

Apollo will close down on June 30th. Reddit’s recent decisions and actions have unfortunately made it impossible for Apollo to continue. Thank you so, so much for all the support over the years.

This paying for API usage is becoming the ‘sign of the times’, first with Twitter now with Reddit. While I don’t use Reddit often, I do use Apollo when I read Reddit. It’s a really good app by an Indie developer and it’s sad to see such a good product go. The thread on how the talks between Apollo and Reddit went is worth the read.

items.title: WWDC 2023 thoughts
items.content_html: Some random thoughts noted during the WWDC event of tonight.
items.content_text:
Some random thoughts noted during the WWDC event of tonight.
  • 15” MacBook Air, great design and great laptop for sure. There is a lot of value here for a large group of consumers. Given the power of Apple Silicon this will be a very powerful laptop for most users. The Mac still has no touch screen, compared to for instance Windows laptops today, but I guess that’s because macOS isn’t ready for it (yet). A touch screen in a MacBook would probably also eat away margin from the iPad Pro segment which Apple doesn’t want.
  • The updates to Phone App are nice but for my usage not needed. I guess the ‘poster’ functionality would be something I setup once and then just forget.
  • Live voicemail probably needs to be supported by the operator and by language. Given that visual voicemail still hasn’t arrived with Vodafone in the Netherlands I’m not expecting anything soon on this.
  • I appreciate the updates to the ‘Messages’ app, I wish more people would use it over WhatsApp so I could get rid of WhatsApp completely.
  • NameDrop is cool, makes perfect sense. I hope it’s more reliable then AirDrop.
  • Inline text predictions, yes please.
  • Journal is nice but I prefer DayOne for this, especially when DayOne incorporates the provided API to capture for instance my exercises.
  • Standby is appreciated, I hope it works well with focus mode so that you can link specific widgets to standby mode. I already have the needed [stand](https://www.twelvesouth.com/products/forte-for-iphone) next to my bed. It wasn’t mentioned but I guess you need an iPhone with an always on display for this.
  • Interactive widgets are finally here. This is typical Apple, calling something a feature that should of been part of the initial release. The iPadOS lock screen looks amazing, I like the vertical setup of widgets.
  • Desktop widgets in macOS. Amazing how Apple is bringing continuity across the iPhone, iPad and Mac. I already see myself using Flighty, Things and Fantastical widgets on my desktop. Interesting to see that Craig Federighi wasn’t doing his demo using Stage Manager, did Apple already give up on it?
  • Creating web apps from Safari is something I will use often. This functionality will replace my current [Unite 4](https://www.bzgapps.com/unite) setup.
  • FaceTime on Apple TV using continuity camera is nicely done. Would be nice if could watch Formula 1 with friends like this.
  • Creating workouts on your iPhone is a welcomed feature as the current approach is WatchOS only and really not easy to setup. My understanding is that with WatchOS 10 it’s now possible through third party apps that support the API.
  • No comments on VisionPro except that it’s very cool product engineering. The threshold for adopting such a device is far too high for me for now. I am curious on the first reviews though.

items.title: A longer personal introduction
items.content_html:
I though it would be nice to post a longer personal introduction here similar to the one I have written on personal website camiel.schoonens.nl.

Introduction

My journey in life started 1978 in the south of the Netherlands. I don’t know a lot about my time in that region of the country anymore as we moved around quite a lot as family in the ‘80’s and ‘90’s. Together with my parents and two siblings, we lived in several different places in the Netherlands and in the USA.

My experience in the USA as a young teenager formed me more in life then I would have expected at the time it happened. I’m certain that it’s one of the main reasons of why I like working in international environments today.

Today I’m living in the lovely town of Oudewater. I’m living here since 2006 with my wife and family and it’s the place I always love returning too from any travel that I do.

My hobbies and personal interests are (in random order):

☀️🏖️🏂🚴🏻📸🖥️👨🏼‍💻👨‍👩‍👧‍👦🍇🍻🤓🏃🏻‍♂️🏑🏎️📚

  • Beach holidays(☀️🏖️), at least once a year in the summer and when possible I’ll try to catch some sun around Christmas too. My favorite holiday destinations till date are: France, Italy and the Dutch Caribbean. My wish is to add South-, Thailand and Sweden to this list very soon.
  • I like to snowboard (🏂) in winter season, both with family and with friends.
  • Cycling (🚴🏻) isn’t something that I do often these days but I still enjoy reading about cycling a lot. There is a form of romance around this sport that I really appreciate.
  • Photography (📸) is something I like to practice since the mid-nineties. I make most photo’s during my holidays and business travel. I take photo’s with both my iPhone and my Canon EOS R camera. With the latter I appreciate working with prime lenses (35mm, 50mm, 85mm) the most.
  • I’m an Apple fan boy (🖥️) and I love my work (👨🏼‍💻).
  • I read a lot about Product, Technology, Organizational Change and Innovation to stay up to date with my knowledge (🤓).
  • I’m a father to three children and I’m happily married since 2007 (👨‍👩‍👧‍👦). As I work and travel a lot I choose to spend the remaining time with my family and friends consciously. I enjoy drinking a good glas of wine (🍇) or beer(🍻) and my favorite recipe’s come from the Italian and Indonesian kitchen.
  • If I would be practicing a team sport it would be field hockey (🏑) again. Nowadays I’m at the hockey club every weekend with my children and I try to visit some matches of our Dutch National Team (m/f) a few times a year.
  • I started running (🏃🏻‍♂️) in 2016 as it’s hard for me to combine work with a team sport. I try to run 2 to 3 times a week and I use a running schedule to practice with a reason and goal. I ran 5 half a marathons in the year of 2017, my fastest time for this distance is 1.43.27.
  • Formule 1 (🏎️) is my favorite sport on TV. For me this is the sport where man, machine, technology and innovation come together at it’s best. I’ve been following Formule 1 since the late 80’s thanks to my father and grandfather.
  • I read (📚) quite a lot and a least every night before I go to bed. Reading helps me relax and end the day. I read just about anything, from science articles to novels and from biographies on remarkable people to thrillers.

items.title: Paris
items.content_html:
One of the nice things of living on the European continent; Everything is relatively close by.

I woke up this morning at 06:15 in my own bed in the Netherlands, travelled by high speed train through 3 countries, arrived in Paris at 11:00 for two days of work and enjoyed a nice diner and a city walk this evening with a friend who happens to be here too.

Finished reading: Killing Moon by Jo Nesbø 📚

I enjoyed reading the newest thriller in the ‘Harry Hole’ series a lot. Maybe this is even the best book until date with a great plot twist and a more or less open end for future books on the last page.

Next to the amazing thriller storytelling that Nesbø does, I like the music references that are being made throughout the different books, including this one with references to Nirvana and Fleetwood Mac amongst others.

If you liked the previous books on Hole then for sure read this one too. If you haven’t read the previous books then don’t start with this one as there are far too many references and characters in here that you won’t understand.

For reference, this is the full series (13 books till date) in order:

Up next on my reading list: The newest novel in the ‘Munch & Krüger’ series by Samuel Björk to be released next week on May 30th in the Netherlands.

items.title: My Home Assistant Dashboard - May 2023
items.content_html:
This is my latest iteration of my Home Assistant Dashboard.

The dashboard is arranged in three columns and I view it on my MacBook through a custom WebCatalog app. I’m using WebCatalog over the default Home Assistant Mac app as a personal preference, you could achieve the same resized view in the Home Assistant app too I guess.

The different cards on the dashboard are aligned in three columns, I use the ‘vertical-stack’ card for this. Within the ‘vertical-stack’ I use ‘horizontal-stack’ to align the buttons on the first row. All other cards are using the maximum space available within the vertical stack-card.

Now let’s go over the three columns from left to right and from top to bottom:

Column 1

Column 2

Column 3
items.content_text:
This is my latest iteration of my Home Assistant Dashboard. The dashboard is arranged in three columns and I view it on my MacBook through a custom WebCatalog app. I'm using WebCatalog over the default Home Assistant Mac app as a personal preference, you could achieve the same resized view in the Home Assistant app too I guess. The different cards on the dashboard are aligned in three columns, I use the 'vertical-stack' card for this. Within the 'vertical-stack' I use 'horizontal-stack' to align the buttons on the first row. All other cards are using the maximum space available within the vertical stack-card. Now let’s go over the three columns from left to right and from top to bottom: Column 1
  • A row with 'Mushroom Cards' for my three main light groups in and around the house.
  • A 'Vertical Bar Chart' based on a custom sensor that is counting the amount of days anualy that I'm producing more energy compared to what I'm using from the grid. I call this 'Netneutraal' or grid neutral.
  • A 'Apex Chart Card' that shows the energy produced through my solar panels. I'm using Apex Charts so that I can also show the offset of the total production on the day before today.
  • Another 'Apex Chart Card', this one is showing the temperature in- and outside of the house. The graph shows the past 24 hours from the current hour back.
Column 2
  • A row with two 'Mushroom Cards' showing the thermostat temperature in the house and the current status of the car charger.
  • A 'Vertical Bar Chart' based on a custom sensor that is counting the amount of days anualy that I'm producing more energy compared to the total energy I've consumed that day. I call this 'Energieneutraal' or energy neutral. This is different from being grid neutral but you will need to read this twice to figure that out.
  • A 'Apex Chart Card' that shows the energy consumed since the day started. The grey lines shows the energy consumed pattern of the day before.
  • A 'Apex Chart Card' that shows the gas consumed since the day started. The grey lines shows the gas consumed pattern of the day before.
Column 3
  • Yet another row with 'Mushroom Cards'. These two cards show me if there is a Home Assistant update available and if my Synology NAS is up-to-date with the latest software. Clicking on these cards open the change log of the latest update.
  • The third and last'Vertical Bar Chart' on the dashboard. This one shows the amount of money spend on charging my car at home. The sensor gets a reset through an automation on January 1st.
  • Another 'Apex Chart Card' showing the electricity prices per hour. Useful for me as I use these prices to automate my car charging.
  • Another custom card, this one is called 'Entity-Row' which I use together with 'Auto Entities' to automatically sort the entities shown (Waste collection types) by date. This card is based on a custom component called 'Afvalwijzer', very useful for Home Assistant users living in the Netherlands.

items.title: Converting W to kWh in Home Assistant
items.content_html:
I’ve been measuring my solar panel production in Home Assistant ever since the panels were installed and I really like the insights that this has been giving me on a daily basis.

Home Assistant has a really nice build-in energy dashboard in which I was able to capture the total produced power of all my solar panels combined by default. This in itself already gave good insights on the daily production but I wanted to refine the insights a bit more as I have two groups of solar panels, one group facing east, one group facing west. You can imagine that depending on the day and season the production on the east and west side of the house differs.

When going through the Home Assistant sensors that my inverter ‘SMA Solar’ provides I noticed that there are actually Watt (W) sensors available for each of the panel groups. These sensors just weren’t showing up as source data for the energy dashboard.

After some reading on the internet I figured out that the reason that I can’t add these sensors to the default energy dashboard is because it expects kilowatt (kWh) sensors. Once you know this it’s relatively easy to convert W to kWh with the Riemann sum integral integration in Home Assistant with the code below.

All you need to do is add the above code (adjusted to your personal source sensor naming) in your configuration.yaml. You will need one platform integration per source sensor. After saving your yaml file and rebooting Home Assistant you can add the new sensors (sensor.energy_produced_east_panels and sensor.energy_produced_west_panels) to your Energy Dashboard resulting in the solar production view below.

I've been measuring my solar panel production in Home Assistant ever since the panels were installed and I really like the insights that this has been giving me on a daily basis. Home Assistant has a really nice build-in energy dashboard in which I was able to capture the total produced power of all my solar panels combined by default. This in itself already gave good insights on the daily production but I wanted to refine the insights a bit more as I have two groups of solar panels, one group facing east, one group facing west. You can imagine that depending on the day and season the production on the east and west side of the house differs. When going through the Home Assistant sensors that my inverter 'SMA Solar' provides I noticed that there are actually Watt (W) sensors available for each of the panel groups. These sensors just weren't showing up as source data for the energy dashboard. After some reading on the internet I figured out that the reason that I can't add these sensors to the default energy dashboard is because it expects kilowatt (kWh) sensors. Once you know this it's relatively easy to convert W to kWh with the Riemann sum integral integration in Home Assistant with the code below. 
- platform: integration
  # Change the below source sensor
  source: sensor.stp6_0_3av_40_341_pv_power_a
  # Change the new sensor name below
  name: energy_produced_east_panels
  unit_prefix: k
  round: 2
- platform: integration
  # Change the below source sensor  
  source: sensor.stp6_0_3av_40_341_pv_power_b
  # Change the new sensor name below
  name: energy_produced_west_panels
  unit_prefix: k
  round: 2
All you need to do is add the above code (adjusted to your personal source sensor naming) in your configuration.yaml. You will need one platform integration per source sensor. After saving your yaml file and rebooting Home Assistant you can add the new sensors (sensor.energy_produced_east_panels and sensor.energy_produced_west_panels) to your Energy Dashboard resulting in the solar production view below.

Mac OS X Rancho Cucamonga — Basic Apple Guy 🔗

A wallpaper based on a joke that got taken way too far. To get everyone up to speed, at WWDC14, in the early days of the transition from OS's named after big cats (Lion, Jaguar, Tiger, Leopard, etc.) to places in California, Craig Federighi joked about Apple's "Crack Marketing Team" driving around California in search of the next name for OS X. Before unveiling OS X Yosemite; Apple teased about considering OS X Oxnard, OS X Weed, and yes, OS X Rancho Cucamonga.

Yet again a stunning wallpaper for all your Apple devices from Basic Apple Guy. I'm still using the Salturn Study 03 wallpaper on my iPhone, iPad and MacBook, but I guess I will be switching to these soon.
